docs.lead_paragraph: Politicians of all stripes are charging that the last few days have marked a revival of one of New York's least proud political traditions: trying to gain advantage by manipulating who is or is not on the ballot. Seven Republican state senators facing tough challenges have sued the tiny Working Families Party, making a fairly novel argument that it is not a legally functioning party. Not incidentally, all seven Republicans tried to get the Working Families nomination but failed, and the party's line went to their Democratic challengers.
docs.abstract: Political operatives are reviving New York's old tradition of trying to manipulate who is or is not on ballot; seven Republican state senators facing tough challenges sue to push tiny Working Families Party off ballot after it endorses Democrats; Democrats on Board of Elections block effort to knock four little-known names off US Senate primary ballot, in hopes of diluting anti-Hillary Clinton vote (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A picture caption yesterday about an event at which Hillary Rodham Clinton spoke, urging Congress to help victims of domestic violence, misstated the location. It was in the Eisenhower Executive Office Building, not at the White House.

docs.lead_paragraph: As Hillary Rodham Clinton was leaving a news conference in White Plains earlier this week, she noticed a small group of reporters gathered on the street. Mrs. Clinton walked past her Secret Service contingent and, with no aides in sight, struck up a conversation about how, by her account, she had just mishandled a question about gay marriage. Mrs. Clinton chatted for nearly five minutes before retreating to her motorcade. It was a moment entirely out of character.
docs.abstract: Adam Nagourney, in Political Memo column, holds that Hillary Rodham Clinton has constructed largely controlled and often remote existence in seven months since she began traveling around New York as prospective candidate for US Senate; maintains that there are signs of thaw as she prepares to formally announce her candidacy; cites her recent appearance on Late Show With David Letterman (M)

headline.main: Political Memo; Hillary Clinton Is Coming Out of Her Cocoon

docs.lead_paragraph: After weeks of traveling throughout the state, Hillary Rodham Clinton's ''listening tour'' stopped yesterday for the first time in New York City, where she held a discussion about education in a section of Brooklyn that is expected to be solidly behind her all-but-announced campaign for the Senate. Mrs. Clinton's 90-minute session took her to the Concord Baptist Church, a landmark religious institution in Bedford-Stuyvesant.
docs.abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton, after weeks of traveling throughout New York State on so-called 'listening tour,' stops for first time in New York City where she holds discussion about education at Concord Baptist Church in Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn; she listens to host of people offer criticisms and observations about problems in inner city education, from need for smaller class sizes and improved after-school programs to dissatisfaction about lack of foreign-language courses; photo (M)

headline.main: Hillary Clinton Stops Off to Listen in Brooklyn

docs.lead_paragraph: As she inches closer to running for senator from New York, Hillary Rodham Clinton is preparing to build a campaign around education, family and health care issues -- the areas where she has the clearest record of accomplishment, and failure, Democrats close to the First Lady say. Those three areas would be a natural focus of Mrs. Clinton's campaign, because she cares passionately about them and has become a leading Administration voice on all three. For someone who has never run for office, Mrs. Clinton has also established a remarkably long and detailed track record on the issues during two decades of public life.
docs.abstract: Democrats close to Hillary Rodham Clinton say she is preparing to build a campaign for Senate in New York around education, family and health care issues; says she cares passionately about these issues and has developed encyclopedia expertise on them; say these issues are also of paramount importance to voters today and will provide the sharpest contrasts between her and Mayor Rudolph Giuliani, her likeliest Republican opponent; photo (M)

headline.main: First Lady Could Build a Race on Her Best Issues, Allies Say

docs.lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton swept through Macedonia today on a visit that illustrated Washington's continuing struggle to balance the diverse strands of its Kosovo policy. In a refugee camp appearance so carefully scripted that Administration officials chose which refugees Mrs. Clinton would speak with, she commiserated with Kosovo's expelled masses. After hearing refugees' accounts of their flight from Kosovo, she said their plight reminded her of movie depictions of the Holocaust like ''Schindler's List.''
docs.abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton makes carefully orchestrated visit to Macedonia, illustrating Washington's continuing struggle to balance diverse strands of its Kosovo policy; she commiserates with ethnic Albanians at refugee camp, but goes out of her way to avoid offending Macedonian sensibilities; ethnic Macedonians generally oppose NATO's bombing and fear their country will be overrun with fleeing ethnic Albanians; Clinton seeks to defuse anti-American sentiment and to bolster Macedonia's fragile coalition Govermment (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Memo to future Presidential spouses: If you're feeling overlooked, float a rumor that you might run for the Senate. So many people were dying to pay $150 or more to hear Hillary Rodham Clinton's luncheon address at the Plaza yesterday that hundreds were exiled from the main dining room, eating lunch with a public address system. The place was abubble with incipient feminist triumphalism and plain old Democratic opportunism. The press corps trailing Mrs. Clinton was perhaps not as large as the contingent that turned up when the former Vice-Presidential candidate Geraldine Ferraro announced she was running for the Senate in 1992. But it was big considering that Mrs. Clinton was not announcing anything more earth-shaking than her belief that ''this is a great time to be a woman in America.'' It is not every day you see men from the British tabloids virtually weeping in frustration at their inability to get a good position to cover an address about the importance of public commitment.
docs.abstract: Gail Collins Editorial Observer column discusses possibility that Hillary Rodham Clinton will run for Senate; notes that most of 1,000 women who attended her luncheon address at Plaza Hotel on March 3 hoped that she would announce her candidacy (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Seven Sundays ago you started all this,'' Tim Russert told Senator Robert G. Torricelli on NBC's ''Meet the Press'' yesterday, alluding to the Senator's comment on an earlier program that he would like Hillary Rodham Clinton to run for the Senate from New York. ''I was just making small talk,'' answered Mr. Torricelli, a New Jersey Democrat. ''You made it into a national issue.''
docs.abstract: Caryn James column on heavy television news speculation about whether Hillary Rodham Clinton will run for Senate in New York (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The budget debate roiling Congress took human form in midtown Manhattan yesterday as thousands of people -- including health care workers, hospital executives, union officials and Democratic politicians -- marched up Broadway to protest the proposed Republican reductions to the current spending on Medicare and Medicaid. Underscoring the event's partisan overtones, Hillary Rodham Clinton joined the marchers as they massed in Times Square at the height of rush hour. She promised the crowd -- who shouted and waved banners propped up with folded umbrellas -- that her husband would veto any budget that cut too deeply into the two vast Federal health care programs.

headline.main: Workers March to Protest Medicare and Medicaid Cutbacks
